a b s t r a c t
Photocatalytic materials are attracting attention as emerging resources for agricultural applications. This timely review assesses the current developments in the use of biocompatible titanium dioxide (TiO2)based photocatalytic nanomaterials (TiO2-PN) as models to unravel agricultural growth, harvest, and post-harvest problems. Such developments can lead to technological innovations aimed at addressing the pressing global environmental challenges faced by farming. TiO2-PN have been used as antimicrobial, growth-regulating, and fertilizer-like agents. The promising agricultural research applications of TiO2-PN are highlighted along with a discussion of the main challenges that will need to be overcome to fully understand the roles of TiO2-PN in the sustainable and productive exploitation of land and water for agricultural applications under natural conditions. In particular, rhizosphere internalization, translocation, and plant bioaccumulation pathways of photocatalytic materials from environmental exposition are outlined to illustrate the effect of TiO2 on the agricultural cycle. Nanotoxicology and regulations are also discussed to illustrate the importance of biocompatibility and green synthesis of nanomaterials for safe use in real applications. This overview is focused on motivating and intensifying our understanding of on-site agricultural studies. Complementary biological approaches and structural damage observed by biological transmission electron, scanning electron, and optical microscopies should accelerate the practical contribution of TiO2-PN to sustainable agriculture in conjunction with plant factories and plasma nitrogen fixation technology. Loadings below 10 g/L of TiO2-PN with a size of 40 nm benefit seed germination and root elongation as well as partially suppressing metal root translocation. However, only approximately 5% of current studies were carried out in real agricultural settings.

Dr. Vicente Rodríguez-González is a Senior Research Scientist at the Institute for Scientific and Technological Research of San Luis Potosi (IPICyT-Mexico). He received his B.S. in Chemical Engineering (1999) and M.S. (2002) in Mexico City and his Ph.D. (2006) from the Université Pierre et Marie Curie (Paris VI) in France. He was a visiting professor for a year at the Photocatalysis International Research Center at Tokyo University of Science and a Brain Pool Program Fellow (2015) through the Korean Federation of Science and Technology Societies. His research interests are focused on the Environmental Materials Science and New Nanostructures for Green Chemistry and Heterogeneous Photocatalysis.
Dr Chiaki Terashima received his Ph.D. degree (2003) in Electrochemical Analysis from the University of Tokyo under the supervision of Profs. A. Fujishima and K. Hashimoto. His academic career started at Nagoya University as an Associate Professor (2010–2011) in Prof. O. Takai’s group, and then moved to Tokyo University of Science in 2012. He is currently a Professor at the Photocatalysis International Research Center, Tokyo University of Science. His research interests focus on photoelectrochemistry, diamond electrochemistry, and plasma processing in liquids.
Professor Akira Fujishima received his Ph.D. in Applied Chemistry from the University of Tokyo in 1971. He taught at Kanagawa University for four years and then moved to the University of Tokyo, where he became a Professor in 1986. In 2003, he retired from this position and took on the position of Chairman of the Kanagawa Academy of Science and Technology. On January 1st 2010, he became President of Tokyo University of Science (TUS). Now he is a Distinguished Professor and Director of the Photocatalysis International Research Center at TUS. His main interests are in photocatalysis, photochemistry, and diamond electrochemistry.
. Introduction and background
Agriculture has been and will continue to be the core reaon for human development; in fact, the current top ten nations ith the largest gross domestic products have economies based n the agricultural crop sector, thus making it important to estabish their infrastructure and adapt agriculture to new green energy echnologies such as biofuels [1]. Agricultural harvest is vital for opulation health and economic equilibrium (import and export), hich directly reflects the development and security of a country. aluable agricultural crops such as cereals like corn, rice, and wheat equire extensive land areas and specific climate conditions for uitable and efficient harvesting. Arable land in square kilometers y country is represented on the world map in Fig. 1 [1,2]. The diferent agricultural products produced by various countries depend n nation, culture, and type of land, ranging from fruits, vegetables, eeds, roots, and flowers as direct food products to indirect food
products for livestock; there are also secondary economic activities associated with products such as wood, pollen, natural fertilizers, compost, and seeds for oil or extract production and processed materials [2–4]. The introduction of new agricultural technologies such as photovoltaic greenhouses, aquaculture systems, automatic irrigation systems, crop rotation, synthetic biology, vertical farming, fungicides, and fertilizers has facilitated the harvesting and cultivation of out-of-season products even in very cold regions with unsuitable natural conditions [3–5]. Eco-friendly methods from hydroponic systems to light-emitting diode (LED)-lit insulated greenhouses have been developed over the last decade [5–7]. However, considerable health and environmental problems have been caused by the indiscriminate use of pesticides and harmful fertilizers; also, the close cultivation of crops has increased water pollution and soil wear, which has contributed to both climate change and agricultural issues. The global population is expected to rise to 10 billion in 2050, which will increase the demand for food and agricultural products [1,2,8]. The Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) has forecast that food production will need to increase by 70% between 2020 and 2056 to meet the growing demand for food [1,3–9].
Agriculture currently exerts strong injurious effects on the climate because of its high energy consumption and human consumerism [1,4,8–10]. In this sense, pesticides, which are used to control insects, pests, and weeds, and fertilizers, which contaminate water sources and promote soil erosion, are the leading factors causing agricultural and environmental pollution. Worn and polluted agricultural soils negatively affect the harvesting process, human health, and economics [1,7,9,10]. Nanotechnology is an emerging approach that may help to overcome these problems and lead to sustainable agriculture. These problems have started to be studied and solved using nanomaterials as adsorbents, catalysts, delivery systems, fertilizer-like agents, and antibacterial solids [9–12]. Photocatalytic materials are the most viable and sustainable option to overcome the current agriculture environmental challenges. In particular, titanium dioxide (TiO2)-based photocatalytic nanomaterials (TiO2-PN) have been considered as models to understand the importance of their structure, photoactivity, chemical stability, tunable hydrophilicity, and biocompatibility to achieve sustainable agriculture. TiO2-based materials show advantages over synthetic metallic nanomaterials, which are unstable in water, and absorbent carbon-based nanomaterials, which are porous [11–18].
TiO2 materials have been studied comprehensively in physicochemical, toxicological, and biocompatibility studies [17–20]. Photocatalysis is an eco-friendly nanotechnology approach that limits the formation of by-products and has the possibility of reaching contaminant mineralization under natural agricultural conditions. Photocatalysis also works under artificial light and

2. Features of photoactive TiO2-based materials
2.1. Artificial photosynthesis as an eco-friendly alternative energy source
Photosynthesis is a process that uses the solar irradiation to produce carbohydrates mainly from water and carbon dioxide (CO2), which are available at the plant surface. This natural chemical process is crucial in agriculture because plants depend on it to grow. Corn must be cultivated in areas where it will obtain at least six to eight hours of sun each day. Animals, including humans, need to metabolize carbohydrates to obtain both chemical and thermal energy; animals only require maximum a couple of hours of sunlight to generate substances like vitamin D, which is important for skin and vision [20,25]. Photocatalysis is an artificial reaction in which a semiconductor uses light energy to accelerate certain reactions. Under irradiation, a semiconductor promotes an electron from its valence band to its conduction band, which activates electrons and holes. Thus, the semiconductor surface acts as a chemical nanocell and the excited semiconductor functions as a photocatalyst [18–20,25]. This short-lived surface phenomenon may disrupt molecules adsorbed on the TiO2-PN surface, causing electron transfer, which is a redox process that is regulated the positions of the photocatalyst energy levels. In this sense, ways to tailor the photocatalytic properties of TiO2 are already well known and have been comprehensively reviewed [18,20,25]. Photocatalysts can be used as powders in slurry systems or as coatings and thin films, in aqueous media, vapor- and gas-phase reactors, and also in solar practical applications like solar disinfection and solar plants [18,26–29]. In addition to the activity of TiO2-based photocatalysis, application conditions, reactor geometry, light source, and mass transfer, among other factors, have to be considered when focusing on agricultural uses.
Artificial photosynthesis is an emerging technology that can be used as an alternative energy source. Direct solar irradiation can provide energy to hydroponic greenhouses and plant factories that also require antimicrobial materials and materials for nitrogen and CO2 fixation. The biocompatibility and non-toxicity of TiO2based materials used in artificial photocatalytic reactions is of great importance [7,9,12,17].

2.2. Biocompatibility of sustainable materials
The reuse, recycling, and/or recovery of TiO2-PN from agricultural, medicine and food security applications are of great importance [8,30–35]. The ability of some plants to metabolize toxic substances and recover from their exposure is also affected by concentration [15,16]. The evolution of photocatalytic materials in the agricultural network needs to be investigated [8,12,16,17,19,33]. The short- and long-term processes affecting TiO2-PN and TiO2-PN aggregation in soil, roots, tissues, stems,

Important regulatory international agencies uch as the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency’s (EPA), the uropean Food Safety Authority’s (EFSA), and the World Health rganization (WHO) have established some nanomaterial reguations [34,35], through which the regulation adaptability and hotocatalytic activity of materials will have to be considered. TiO2 as many other uses besides as a photocatalyst—it can be found in hite paint, pigments, paper components, clear plastic, electronic aterials, inks, rubbers, care products such as sunscreen and toothaste, and white chocolate [32,36]. TiO2 has replaced the toxic lead ompounds previous used in paints and varnishes because of its resents transparency. The allowed i concentrations in food and personal care products are under 0 g/mg of food and 100 g/mg of product, respectively [38].
TiO2 possesses the required biocompatibility for agricultural pplications and its viability as a photoactive material is already ppreciated. TiO2 is an attractive photoactive catalyst for the minerlization of residual pollutants, pesticides, and organic compounds n hydroponic cultures and under simulated conditions [39–41]. n addition, TiO2 can behave as an antimicrobial agent of phyopathogenic infections of plants and fruit [15,22,26], which can revent human intoxication through the food web. The effecive immobilization of TiO2 as a photocatalytic film or coating on urfaces will be a crucial advance toward commercial and solar ractical applications in sustainable harvesting, packaging, and torage of vegetables and fruit [42–48], avoiding the need for TiO2N lixiviation.
Compared with other materials such as carbon-based materials, esoporous silicon dioxide (SiO2) and chitosan, metallic nanoparicles based on gold, silver, or ruthenium, and natural clays, TiO2-PN as the advantages of being photoactive, non-toxic at low concenrations, and highly transparent as a film. TiO2-PN is more viable nd biodegradable than carbon nanostructured materials such as raphene and porous carbon synthesized from natural sources, hich are reported to be toxic to humans [8,16,31,32].
Overall, TiO2-PN offers: (i) tailored photoactivity response to isible and natural solar radiation. In addition, its UV response can e useful for some medical and sensing purposes; (ii) photochem-
cal, physical, and mechanical stability under diverse agricultural onditions; (iii) high hydrophilic mesoporous surface area, with he dimensionality of TiO2 materials ranging from zero to three; (iv) ntibacterial, biocompatible, and biodegradable properties; and (v) he possibility of being used as transparent coatings or thin films n packing plastics, reactors, or devices.
.3. Sustainable preparation of green TiO2 nanomaterials
Most TiO2-PN are synthesized using commercial P25 vonik/Degussa with anatase/rutile crystalline phases as a recursor. Modification of P25 by hydro/solvothermal and thermal rocesses can provide nanotubes, fibers, and wire morphologies; itanates with cube-like morphologies; and faceted materials ith high surface area, among others [12,22,49–52]. Other more laborate methodologies are also available, like the sol–gel method 50,53,54] for doping with metallic and organic cations, sonohemical treatment, and metallic surface functionalization with ransition and noble metal nanoparticles [18,26,52,53]. A less ustainable approach is electrochemical anodization for nantube growth and physical production of thin films and coatings 50,55,56].
Visible and solar responses have been achieved from these TiO2ased frameworks after doping and/or surface modification using rocesses adapted from heterogeneous catalysis. Sustainable synhesis requires a short reaction process, typically from minutes to
otobiology C: Photochemistry Reviews 40 (2019) 49–67 53
hours. However, if a process is to be scaled up, the reaction time lengthens [22,50,53] and energy requirements change. To achieve the green synthesis of materials, the procedure has to avoid further thermal stabilization without generating toxic residues or at least involve recovery and/or recycling stages [22,50,57,58]. These key parameters affect the synthesis route and its direct relationship with in-situ processes to obtain active surface coatings and photocatalytic films with high stability to allow continuous operation [55].
The stability of materials depends on temperature, mechanical properties in aqueous media, and vapor contact. It is also important to modify the hydrophilicity to superhydrophilicity to inhibit the surface saturation and promote continuous operation or reuse after a fast surface regeneration process [48].
Another way to increase the heterogeneous photocatalytic effect of TiO2-PN is by injecting dry air or oxygen (O2) into the system to promote the generation of ROS because an inert gas such as N2 favors reduction. Addition of scavenger molecules such as sodium sulfite, hydrazine, hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), or ozone (O3) can increase photocatalytic activity [59,60] but also increases the cost and may complicate the understanding of the system mechanism. Modification of the system pH can exert detrimental effects by making it difficult to scale up the system for practical applications. Selectivity and kinetics can be controlled using pH, but it has to be kept in mind that the goal is to operate under the natural conditions of agricultural systems. Cheap and practical conditions to fabricate photocatalysts for sustainable agricultural applications are currently being investigated, as summarized in Fig. 4.
3. Recent growth, harvest and post-harvest agricultural applications
3.1. Effects of TiO2-PN on crop land, plant germination, fertilization, harvesting, and disease control
Germination of seeds to achieve a cost-effective harvesting process can be challenging because of the possible contamination of seeds during storage with fungus or bacteria that could damage the germination or development of plants or roots, affecting the quality of the products. In addition, fertilizers are sources of microbial and toxic pollution that has detrimental effects. Some compost and organic fertilizers are mixed with well-rotted animal manure and pelletized with chicken blood and bone that may contain hormonal and bacterial remains. On farms, the bioaccumulation of external particles occurs in soils [33,61,63,64]. Pollutants from other air and water sources may concentrate and accumulate in soils, which are the major contaminant source of nanoparticles. When taking a plant as a model, the roots are the main source for TiO2PN internalization as a contaminant from the rhizosphere [33]. Powder aggregates and dust accumulated in the leaves, fruit, and flowers are carried to the stem and roots by rain and irrigation. In addition, the possible translocation from the roots to the fruit has been reported; a stomatal leaf route is also likely [33,64–66]. The detrimental effects of bioaccumulation of nanoparticle aggregates and their plant internalization has been studied in detail in specialized plant physiology reviews [8,16,17,33,64–67]. In short, only nanoparticles less than 50 nm in size might penetrate (i) the epidermis of roots and then undergo a complex series of biochemical events to reach the xylem and translocate to the stem, fruit, or flowers; (ii) through foliar interaction via stomata or cuticle. That is, the hydrophilic particles might be internalized through stomata pores and then translocate to different plant parts, as shown in Fig. 5. Pests and microbial infections originate from insects, mites, or air on stems and leaves. In contrast, the main contaminants come from chemical fertilizers and contaminated water. In

Overall, beneficial and negative effects of TiO2-PN on germination and plant growth have been reported, which depend on experimental factors such as hydroponic conditions, soil type, humidity, agglomeration of TiO2-PN, photoresponsivity, and nanoparticle agglomeration. In this sense, standardization as soon as possible is crucial to carry out comparable evaluations by considering factors such as TiO2 loading, humidity, isoelectric point, size aggregation, main crystalline phase of TiO2, and hydrophilicity, focusing on real conditions. TiO2 may enhance water adsorption in the rhizosphere zone or promote photosynthesis if foliar contact occurs. As a result, germination or root and/or shoot elongation may be facilitated because of root oxygenation through exposure to ROS and hydroxide (OH) [8,16,32].
3.2. Translocation and bioaccumulation of nanomaterials on plants
3.2.1. Potential TiO2-PN pathways for plant translocation Bioaccumulation and translocation of TiO2-PN from the rhizosphere area around plants appear likely and may disturb plant growth, photosynthesis, and nutrient contents. Photosensitivity is an advantage of TiO2-PN over carbon, iron oxides, and clay nanomaterials, which means that TiO2-PN are capable of not only performing surface reactions because of their suitable morphology and adsorption properties, but also promote photocatalysis for agricultural applications with low loading requirements.
Table 1 summarizes the effects of TiO2-PN on five of the principal foodstuffs globally in 2017 [82]. Short-term and direct interactions of TiO2-PN with agricultural products include the disruption of photosynthesis, morphology changes, bioaccumulation, effects on nutrients, and potential translocation [83–92].
Experiments on hydroponic maize cultures [88,89,91], wheat (Triticum aestivum) [85–90], and tomato plants [85,88,89] revealed that colloidal suspensions of TiO2 nanoparticles with an average size of 30 nm present in hydroponic and soil media influenced the hydraulic dissemination through the wall pores (6.6 nm) of the primary roots on, which affected the transpiration and growth of the leaves. The formation of micronuclei in wheat plant roots indicated that TiO2-PN induced genotoxicity at loadings of 80–100 mg/kg, which may be caused by the increased production of H2O2 species. At loadings lower than 60 mg/kg, a beneficial effect was observed even if TiO2 nanoparticles with a size of around 20 nm accumulated in the roots. In addition, 60 mg/kg was the optimal concentration to enhance shoot and root lengths, chlorophyll concentration, and biomass production in wheat [85]. The results in Table 1 suggest that TiO2-PN does not display severe toxicity during germination and early harvest of these five foodstuffs. Translocation and bioaccumulation of TiO2-PN occurred under laboratory conditions when the nanoparticle size was less than 30 nm. However, most studies did not consider hydrodynamic diameter or the actual concentration of TiO2. 3.2.2. Bioaccumulation of heavy metals and the role of TiO2-PN as a mediator
Toxic heavy metals such as lead (Pb) can bioaccumulate in food crops such as rice and vegetables, leading to health risks [65,85,92]. TiO2 can lower the Pb concentration in rice seedling roots by as much as 80% [67]. The presence of TiO2-PN in a hydroponic medium did not influence rice seedling biomass even at a high concentration of 1000 mg/L. Only the anatase TiO2 crystalline phase was accumulated by rice seedling roots without translocation. Although TiO2-PN (100–500 mg/mL) lowered the contents of carbohydrates and sugars in rice tissues, the biosynthetic formation of most of the identified lipids, amino acids, and secondary metabolites that reflected crop quality increased [86]. The presence of TiO2 increased the accumulation of 133Cs, a stable isotope of cesium, in soybean plants because the photosynthesis rate increased [87]. In addition, seed germination and plant growth rates were enhanced by adding TiO2 to the soil. However, the protein concentration was increased in both the TiO2-treated and control systems. The uptake of 133Cs was found to be higher in the shoot than in the root, which indicates that this plant is favorable for the remediation of 133Cs-polluted soil but not for use as a foodstuff.
Arsenic (As) bioaccumulation and speciation in cultivars of maize and rice and As translocation from agricultural soils have been studied [93,94]. The toxicological risks associated with consumption of As-containing corn and corn-based food products need to be considered. As translocation and speciation in corn crops leads to oxidative stress and affects the plant development as well as transforming As into a more toxic agent for humans [94]. The As concentration in maize tissues increased in the order of grain < stem < leaf < root. The As concentration in corn and rice foodstuffs was reported to be in the range of 0.04 to 1.13 mg/kg, exceeding the maximum permissible concentration. 3.2.3. Reproducible plant sample preparation to ensure accurate interpretation of translocation and bioaccumulation
Protocols for reproducible plant characterization using advanced techniques for elementary chemical analysis, biological microscopies (AFM, TEM, and SEM), inductively coupled plasma–mass spectrometry (ICP-MS), advanced surface techniques, and genetic analysis, need to be standardized [22,64,65,96,97]. For example, ultrasonication before TEM and SEM characterization affects the size and agglomeration of TiO2-PN and also the high-vacuum environment inside such instruments should be considered to obtain reliable data for interpretation.
Allotropic forms of TiO2-PN possess high thermodynamic, chemical, and mechanical stabilities. In contrast, carbon, metallic, and other soluble oxide nanoparticles such cerium oxide, zinc oxide, and iron oxides are photocorrosive or highly soluble in aqueous environments. Silver forms diverse species in humid environments; these types of unstable particles must be avoided in agricultural applications because of their translocation and toxicity risks [63,64,88,92].
Harvest and post-harvest processes are also possible points for seed contamination if on-field operations of plant and seed collection possess poor hygiene, which increases the contamination of the stored seeds [98]. Disease control is important in seed germination to prevent low germination and growth problems affecting roots and shoots. Such issues can be controlled by the pathophys-

.3. Harvest disease control and eradication of infection by athogen microorganisms
The rapid contamination of water sources, environmental air ollution, overexploitation of soil, and adverse climate changes re the main factors behind the infection of crops by pathogenic icroorganisms. Vast cultivation is vulnerable to pathogenic icroorganism infections promoted by fungi and bacteria, which eproduce easily if plants are located close to each other. As a esult, numerous plant diseases can easily devastate agricultural rops. Necrosis, tissue maceration, wilting, and hyperplasia are ust some of the results of diseases affecting agricultural food 22,68,89,98,99]. Many pathogenic microorganisms first induce ater-related injuries in the host plant, followed by necrosis nd chlorosis of the tissues. TiO2-based materials have shown he ability to swiftly stop and eradicate bacteria and fungi from lants [15,22,99] under laboratory agricultural conditions. ROS nd electron–hole pairs attack microorganisms by disturbing their eproduction and stressing the plant pathogens, but the death proess of these detrimental microorganisms induced by TiO2-based aterials has not been supported by microscopical studies in the iterature. In natural surroundings, latent infections may have a rolonged incubation period because of resistance in the host plant r the presence of an environmental factor. Only the decrease in olony-forming unit (CFU) caused by TiO2-based materials has been eported. Plants exposed to TiO2-based nanomaterials originating rom environmental pollution have shown maximum TiO2 conentrations of 130–3100 g/kg in wastewater, sludge, soils, and ir [16,17,80,97]. At the germination stage, low concentrations of iO2-PN seem to be beneficial to plant development. The exposure f plants to TiO2-PN during the harvesting process occurs logially under solar radiation and the photoactivity of TiO2-PN can e increased through ROS generation [18,20].
Traces of commercial TiO2 materials have been detected by dvanced surface characterization techniques such as ICP-MS, Xay photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and X-ray absorption near dge structure spectroscopy [17,65,66,96]. TiO2-PN traces have een found in stems, leaves, and/or the fruit of tomato, corn, heat, and cucumber plants, among others, as shown in Fig. 6. hese traces have been in the range of nanograms [16,17,30,33,70] nd the detected materials were probably translocated into the oots. The lack of information on the biochemical effects of TiO2
aterials on plants makes it difficult to confirm the negligible ffects of exposure to trace amounts of TiO2 materials in foods n human health compared with that to the hazardous chemials present in air and water (of a size able to enter cells). Size, gglomeration, crystalline phase, and morphology are factors that an alter the artificial photosynthetic processes of TiO2 materils [16,17,30,33,84]. Only dispersed particles less than 50 nm in ize can penetrate leaves and stem pores; such particles are probbly carried to foliage by wind. Nanoparticles in water usually gglomerate and deposit on soil through the action of gravity. The ccumulation of TiO2-PN in farming occurs mainly in soil and may ffect nitrogen fixation by microbial communities and the P content f the rhizosphere [16,91]. Logically, penetration and translocation ikely occurs from roots to the rest of the plant. Fertilizer chemi-
otobiology C: Photochemistry Reviews 40 (2019) 49–67 59
cals, pesticides, and heavy metals are easily translocated into plants [17,64–66,83,84,94]. Pre-harvest bacterial and fungi contamination of roots and leafy greens can occur directly or indirectly via wildlife, insects, fecal water (cattle and human), organic compost, dirty equipment, and human handling [68,98–100]. Greenhouses and plant factories are less prone to microbial contamination because these systems are protected from the outside environment. Microbial infection sources in the greenhouse can be minimized by careful control of irrigation water and fertilization.
3.3.1. Organic agriculture and safe food production Overall, worldwide consumer regulations are more concerned about chemical than microbial contaminants. As a result, global organic agricultural production has been increasing since the 2000s. Regulations governing such production have started to be adjusted because of disease outbreaks reported in recent years in both the USA and Europe, especially those associated with leafy vegetables (spinach, lettuce, and lettuce mixes or salads) contaminated with Salmonella spp. and Escherichia coli O157 [15,68,98,99].
Visible light- and UV-active TiO2-PN can disturb oxygen release and the photosynthetic rate, which affect the germination rate, antioxidant properties, chromosomal aberrations, chloroplast oxygenation, chlorophyll formation, and elongation, influencing the germination of many recently studied plant species like tomato, soybean, onion, and spinach [16,17,22,33]. These effects depend on the TiO2-PN concentration, plant species, harvest stage, exposure pathway, and agricultural conditions. The translocated TiO2 concentration may have a negligible antimicrobial effect on fungi or bacterial infection because of the exponential evolution of bacteria. However, TiO2-PN can prevent the exponential growth of microorganisms in irrigation water applied on the leaves or stems of plants.
The water quality used in the rinse step at harvest is also important. The FDA and European Food Safety Authority have published guides for good agricultural practices concerning fresh fruits and vegetables as control measures to ensure the safety of fresh products. The antimicrobial potential of TiO2PN towards a wide range of bacterial, fungal, algal, and viral organisms that affect agriculture from irrigation to seedling to postharvest processes can help to protect foodstuffs from pathogens [2,13,22,32,38,42–44,46–48,99–105]. For example, a greenhouse study using natural tomato transplants and ones artificially infected with Xanthomonas perforans FL 47 displayed considerably decreased bacterial spot severity after treatment with Zn-doped TiO2. Plants were sprayed with TiO2 formulations until there was runoff from the leaves. Disease severity was established using the Horsfall–Barratt scale. The results achieved using Zn-doped TiO2 were of the same order of magnitude as those for commercial copper bactericides and mancozeb [103]. Parallel in vitro and field experiments using TiO2 and Ag-doped TiO2 illustrated their high photoactivity [103]. The field experiments were conducted in three different places in Florida during 2010 and 2011. The interaction of visible photons with an appropriate TiO2 photocatalyst damaged proximal microbes and those adsorbed on the photocatalyst, decreasing their viability. The modes of action of the TiO2 photocatalyst proposed in the study were the direct oxidation of coenzyme A, which inhibited cell respiration and led to cell death, and changes of cell permeability induced by cytoplasmic membrane damage. Homogenous spraying of the TiO2 photocatalyst over the whole leaf without other cover prevented possible leaf phytotoxicity. This research did not investigate the possible translocation of the TiO2 photocatalyst from leaves or the soil. The limitation of TiO2 composites is their low antibacterial photocatalytic activity in the absence of light, although a bacteriostatic effect is still present. Treatment

3.3.3. Use of TiO2-PN films or coatings in harvest disease control It is important to understand the of annihilation mechanism of pathogens by TiO2-PN to prevent infections using thin films or coatings to increase harvest health and quality. Organic food consumption is increasing, so TiO2-PN represents a promising option to provide safe organic crops. F. verticillioides is a common fungal infection of maize. Other microorganisms like F. graminearum, A. flavus, and P. expansum can affect the seedlings, grains, and stems of maize. Viral diseases are also fairly common in maize. Fungi and viruses can cause sporadic and very damaging epidemics in maize plantations [104]. TiO2 powder and TiO2-coated films have exhibited antifungal activity that helped to control fruit rot development [105]. A TiO2-coated plastic film exhibited photocatalytic activity against P. expansum. The TiO2-coated film did not damage the surface of a lemon. Few practical studies under agricultural or on-site conditions to clarify the effects of TiO2-PN on the harvest of plant species have been conducted. Most studies have been carried out in Petri dishes under laboratory conditions, which limits the understanding of practical situation. Further on-site studies along with biological techniques like genotoxicity, cell or DNA alteration, and structural damage observation by optical and electronic microscopies [22,33] are imperative to accelerate the design of TiO2-PN coatings to increase their beneficial contribution to agriculture.
Artificial photosynthesis is being developed because of the current focus on the generation of energy from CO2 and oxygen, emulating natural photosynthesis [106,107]. . Post-harvest and storage
Post-harvest activity entails more economic losses than other teps of foodstuff production and thus has been thoroughly studied or pathogenic eradication; to this end, antifungal and antimicrobial esistance of the control products is required to prevent microial or fungicide resistance. One advantage of TiO2-PN is that it akes the development of microorganism resistance impossible ecause of its simultaneous photocatalytic, mechanical, and bioidal actions [22,15,101,103,109]. In addition, TiO2-PN, thin films nd coatings are attractive for infection control just before harvest ecause TiO2 shows high transparency and antifouling properties 22,32,37,38,42–46,52,103,105,108]. Low loadings of TiO2-PN can timulate defense expressions such as increasing the protein preursor for oxidative stress tolerance, which helps the plant. Silver pecies may affect the plant defense genes, which encode proteins hat dictate cell function, and in turn influence plant health and the utrient quality of crops. For example, Ag-doped TiO2-PN (18 nm) ith loadings of up to 60 g/mL improved the quality of Oryza ativa (Asian rice) [32]. A chitosan coating doped with TiO2 and SiO2 anoparticles decreased the rates of decay, shrinkage, respiration, thylene production, electrolyte leakage, superoxide anion prouction, and the malondialdehyde accumulation of Ginkgo biloba eeds [108]. The composite with chitosan effectively maintained he post-harvest quality of the seeds during storage for 180 days by nhibiting the proliferation of the external contaminant microbes y regulating the generation of O2, which is involved in oxidation nd defense enzyme activities. The TiO2-PN in coating formulas lay important roles in preserving quality, increasing antimicrobial urface activity, and extending the storage period of seeds. These iO2-PN-doped coatings could be used in commercial applications o maintain the quality and extend the life of G. biloba seeds or other ruits during transportation and storage [105,108,109].
Humans use plants as sources of food, building materials, scents, yes, drugs, and decoration. In the near future, the importance f crop security will be featured in legislation. Currently, the egulations governing the use of nanomaterials in agricultural roducts are at a very early stage. With the increasing demand or organic agriculture, it is important to develop regulations to nsure the safe use of nanomaterials. Another way to control phyopathogenic microbes is the transgenic manipulation of foodstuffs 110]. Transgenic plants have been controversial because farmrs and authorities are uncertain about their safety and regulatory ssues. Moreover, their nutritional properties and taste are not yet learly established. There are also regulatory issues associated with roducts from LED-irradiated plant factories [68,70–72,79,89,110]. he knowledge developed from manipulating the gene expresion in plants will be very helpful to understand the translocation nd bioaccumulation of TiO2-PN. Problems reported for products uch as nitrogen-fixing cereals and As found in vegetables growing lose to mining lands could give insights to establish the quality nd safety of harvested products treated with TiO2-PN. The isotopes of nitrogen can be used to investigate TiO2 translocation, phytotoxicity, and the quality of fresh vegetable products treated with TiO2-PN. In recent studies of Brassica chinensis growth, in which it was difficult to discriminate between organic and conventional production methods, the 15N stable isotope of N was used in a chemometric approach [111,112]. The same approach can probably be used to monitor 15N from TiO2 and fertilizers to determine the safety of foodstuffs from seedlings to final products. 5. Coupled technologies to improve TiO2-PN features
5.1. Plant factories for viable commercial production
The New-Generation Plant Factory, which produces 5000 lettuce plants per day, was built at the R&D Center of the Plant Factory at Osaka Prefecture University, Japan, in September 2014. The isolated plant factory achieved 40% cost savings in growing lettuces. Anpo et al. [7] described the fundamental components and detailed operation of this plant factory. The plant-growing complex includes hydroponics, vertical systems, multilayer racks, isolated solution circuits, LED light sources, air conditioning, and automatic control systems. The delivery and transport of raw materials and harvested products were also automated to guarantee product safety, Fig. 8a. In contrast, thermal- and mass-isolated artificial light hydroponictype plant factories do not require costly air conditioning. Access to this kind of information is limited at present; only reports on lettuce production are found in the currently available literature because most information is protected by companies. Fortunately, this trend is changing and studies are currently being conducted by industrial collaborations in China, Taiwan, Japan, USA, UK, the Netherlands, and Belgium.
To encourage higher participation in this field, horticultural education is offered in some of these countries through courses from vocational to university levels as part of a future vision [7,68]. One of the coupled technologies envisioned for developing plant factories is aquaponics, which is a food production system that combines the recirculation of aquaculture systems for valuable hydroponic systems by using waste matter excreted from fish as an alternative liquid fertilizer. The Aztec and Chinese prehistoric cultures practiced an early method of aquaponics that involved raising fish together with crops, which means that this technology is possible. Aquaponics has enhanced the production of hydroponic vegetables and seaweeds. Although TiO2-PN materials have been used to treat unexpected pathogenic infections, no details were found in the current literature. Photocatalytic hydrogen production using biomass derivatives as hole scavengers and CO2 emitted simultaneously as an oxidation product of biomass derivatives has been used to promote plant growth in plant factories. The addition of various biomass derivatives to hydrogen production systems with LED visible-light irradiation to activate TiO2 thin photocatalytic films led to increases of harvesting rate [7,68–72].

Thundertorms reach electrical equilibrium by releasing lightning, which s extremely violent and can heat the air around it to extremely igh temperatures. This heat causes the surrounding air to rapidly xpand and vibrate, which creates the resonating thunder that we ear a short time after seeing a lightning flash. In a regular storm, he generation of lightning and thunder presents beneficial aspects or the Earth because lightning helps to fertilize plants. The atmophere consists of approximately 78% N2 in the gas phase; however, lants cannot use nitrogen in this form [114]. Lightning strikes elp to dissolve N2 to form a variety of reactive nitrogen species n water together with ROS, which then generate a natural fertilzer that plants can absorb through their roots [114–116]. On the aboratory scale, a gas discharge could be initiated from a power ource in an O2- and N2-containing gas flow, which is ionized to reate ions, radicals, and reactive species, representing a kind of ontrolled artificial lightning. Additionally, combinations of plasma, adsorbents, and photocatalysis have been reported to show synergistic enhancement of growth in plants such as basil and tomatoes [113–119].
The most commonly reported non-thermal plasma sources for water treatment are dielectric barrier discharges using diverse electrode geometries, insulator plates, or tubes [114–118]; Fig. 8b, packed bed reactors containing dielectric or ferroelectric beads or pellets; corona discharge devices, which are mainly operated by direct-current or pulsed high voltage; microwave plasma torches using a waveguide cavity (resonator); and gliding arc discharges, which are characterized by diverging electrodes [114]. The use of non-thermal plasma under ambient conditions allows the insitu generation of liquid fertilizers with an antialgal effect that enhanced the harvest of basil plants. A healthy seed germination process is affected by the amounts of nitrogen compounds and plasma-generated species (ROS, ions, hydrogen radicals). A commercial Hoagland solution containing NH4+, NO3−, K+, and PO4− can be used to support the controlled growth of basil together with Chlorella vulgaris as a model algae species. However, liquid fertilizer generation with an in-situ antialgal outcome for the healthy growth of seeds has seldom been reported. The coupling of these technologies with TiO2-PN and plant factories could be an important advance in the sustainable production of agricultural crops [118,119], Fig. 8c.

. Regulatory aspects of photocatalysis in the agricultural ood sector
Humans and the environment have been exposed to residual ynthetic materials such as automotive fumes, plastics, factory missions, mining slag, volatile residual oxides from metallic corosion, and natural dust from land erosion and pollen since the ndustrial revolution or for even longer. The accumulation and volution in air, water bodies, and soil of such particulate matter as been intensified by environmental factors closely related to uge human populations. The generation and complex evolution f particulate matter from and in cities and the countryside stem rom debris such as waste source, nuclear, and animal confinement perations such as landfills, mining containment, artificial water odies, municipal water, and wastewater treatment, which have ltered ecosystems. Crops are exposed to these pollutants through ust storms and noxious rain or irrigation water. The natural land rosion from Sahara to the USA is well known, but artificial polluion storms can travel from China to the rest of the world [120]. lants are contaminated by these events and by human and anial pathogens that are also dispersed and accumulated in soil and aste land, affecting crops by root transduction or infertility. ticide contamination is also considered an important mechanism that affects agriculture because herbicide resistance can be transferred from farm to farm [16,61–63,109,121,122]. Food security regulation has not yet been extended to artificial nanopesticides and emitted nanoparticles.
Photocatalytic TiO2 materials and particulate matter could damage crops when absorbed or deposited as agglomerates on crop leaves, stems, shoots, fruits, and flowers, decreasing the growth and yield and leading to premature plant death [63–66]. In the case of nanomaterials, their size, morphology, and concentration are factors that could influence their effect on humans through accumulation in agricultural foods and internalization in different products. Bioaerosols generated from agricultural waste used to produce biofertilizers and livestock food have been investigated because of their very toxic biological nature [64,79,80]. Because TiO2-based photocatalyst materials are photoactive, they can disturb the photosynthesis process and promote biome reproduction. Multiple factors need to be studied to regulate TiO2-PN and minimize possible health risks, including (i) gene expression studies to provide regulations regarding the standard concentration and size of TiO2-PN, (ii) reproducible biological electron microscopy and optical studies to determine the effects of agglomerated and isolated nanoparticles adsorbed or/and translocate on plants, (iii) cytotoxicity evolution studies in animal and plant populations to determine the long-term effects and bioaccumulation zones of TiO2-PN on/in these organisms, (iv) studies of the TiO2-PN evolution over time in on-site farming soils, irrigation water bodies, and plants to establish the influence of TiO2-PN on agricultural harvesting (Fig. 9) and (v) studies of nanomaterials for on-site and real agricultural applications. Developing reproducible chemical and biochemical protocols for advanced characterization techniques such as ICP-OES, AFM, DLS, isotope approach evaluation, XPS, electron microscopies, and synchrotron techniques (extended X-ray absorption fine structure and hard X-ray techniques) will be crucial to generate establish worldwide regulations. . Concluding remarks
The use of TiO2 photocatalytic materials for sustainable agriultural purposes will positively affect the human food cycle o overcome the agricultural crisis arising from climate changes aused by an overpopulated world. TiO2 with a particle size of less han 5̃0 nm has been detected in low concentrations (ppb level) n food products grown under laboratory conditions. Translocaion of TiO2 from the soil through roots is the main route for plant nternalization. Foliar permeation has also been detected when the hotoactive materials were not agglomerated. According to the roposed effect of TiO2 on agriculture, as shown in Fig. 9, TiO2 ccumulation can occur through plant interactions with soil, air, nd water containing TiO2. In particular, the accumulation of TiO2 n soils has been focused on through rhizosphere interactions and he composition of microbial communities in soils. The harvested gricultural food products most strongly affected by TiO2 are roots nd bulbs, followed by stems, leaves, fruits, seeds, and finally, flowrs.
Among the benefits of TiO2-PN with a size of 40 nm and loadng below 10 g/L is healthy seed germination, which has been bserved as progressive root elongation. TiO2-PN work as growth egulators; however, the enhancement effect appears to depend on enotype.
The co-existence of TiO2-PN with heavy metals shows the abilty of TiO2 to suppress the rhizosphere translocation of metals and heir speciation; the biomass increase induced by TiO2 could be a
echanism to partially recover metals sourced from root transloation.
Research focused on the effects exerted by photoactive nanoaterials on crops should be conducted. Pilot experiments on the
roduction of ornamental flowers will be a valuable reference to evelop reproducible and standardized protocols and the initial
egislation for crop security. Advanced characterization techniques uch as ICP-OES, AFM, DLS, isoelectric point charge and aggregaion particle size analyses, XPS, biological electron microscopies, nd hard X-ray diffraction techniques can be used to evaluate the tomic interactions between TiO2 materials and plant parts. In ddition, studies on biochemical and genetic expression and adeuate cytotoxicity methodologies for roots, stems, leaves, fruits, eeds, and flowers without modifying real conditions are fun-
otobiology C: Photochemistry Reviews 40 (2019) 49–67
damental to reach the appropriate legislation. Nitrogen isotope labeling can provide valuable information to unravel TiO2 translocation and phytotoxicity and measure the quality of fresh vegetable products.
Internalization in plants is the main risk of TiO2-PN. To suppress this, TiO2-PN can be supported on a green inert or biocompatible matrix to inhibit lixiviation and allow their separation and reuse. Many technologies have already been developed for this purpose, ranging from sol–gel immersion techniques to thin-film preparation. Available supports include various types of natural and artificial cotton tissues; for hydroponic greenhouses, coconut fibers, transparent glass/bioplastics, and mesoporous silica materials are used as supports.
Non-thermal plasma technology can be used in conjunction with TiO2 for in-situ fertilization and nitrogen fixation in plant factories to realize healthy industrial growth of sustainable crops.
Implementing TiO2-PN will facilitate sustainable agriculture, but it may also have detrimental health effects and bioaccumulate in ecosystems. The use of TiO2-PN has to be judiciously increased to control water contamination and improve the current nonsustainable agricultural practices that have contributed to climate change. Many toxic anthropogenic and artificial nanoparticles are already present in agricultural ecosystems. Nanoparticles, carbon compounds, and metals from factories and automotive exhaust gases, aluminosilicates from soil erosion, and many other chemical particles are known to be toxic and even carcinogenic, like bioaerosols and Arsenic species. Such particulate matter is already present in the food network and humans.
Education of coming generations to ensure the correct management of natural resources is very important. Environmental education will promote the development of sustainable alternative energy sources to lower the negative environmental effects of megacities.
Corn production has evolved over time through the selection of the corn kernels planted by farmers. A diverse range of plant species should be developed to aid crop protection. TiO2-PN can help to control microbial diseases in crops and other foodstuffs. TiO2-PN can also be used for in-situ detoxification of pesticide remains in irrigation waters by providing a supply of ROS when activated by solar or artificial irradiation. Light irradiation of TiO2-PN on plants increases the photosynthesis effect, which enhances germination and root elongation.
It is imperative for modern agriculture to become sustainable and safe. The combination of helpful belongings of TiO2-based nanomaterials, the ethical genetic manipulations, advanced characterization techniques, and farmers’ experience can improve understanding and yield advanced applications to achieve a new eco-friendly era in agriculture. Environmental education of coming generations to highlight the importance of biodiversity is crucial to guarantee the sustainability of future agriculture. Prevention rather that amending environmental agricultural challenges will be important in the new agricultural era.

metadata.abstractText: Photocatalytic materials are attracting attention as emerging resources for agricultural applications. This timely review assesses the current developments in the use of biocompatible titanium dioxide (TiO2)based photocatalytic nanomaterials (TiO2-PN) as models to unravel agricultural growth, harvest, and post-harvest problems. Such developments can lead to technological innovations aimed at addressing the pressing global environmental challenges faced by farming. TiO2-PN have been used as antimicrobial, growth-regulating, and fertilizer-like agents. The promising agricultural research applications of TiO2-PN are highlighted along with a discussion of the main challenges that will need to be overcome to fully understand the roles of TiO2-PN in the sustainable and productive exploitation of land and water for agricultural applications under natural conditions. In particular, rhizosphere internalization, translocation, and plant bioaccumulation pathways of photocatalytic materials from environmental exposition are outlined to illustrate the effect of TiO2 on the agricultural cycle. Nanotoxicology and regulations are also discussed to illustrate the importance of biocompatibility and green synthesis of nanomaterials for safe use in real applications. This overview is focused on motivating and intensifying our understanding of on-site agricultural studies. Complementary biological approaches and structural damage observed by biological transmission electron, scanning electron, and optical microscopies should accelerate the practical contribution of TiO2-PN to sustainable agriculture in conjunction with plant factories and plasma nitrogen fixation technology. Loadings below 10 g/L of TiO2-PN with a size of 40 nm benefit seed germination and root elongation as well as partially suppressing metal root translocation. However, only approximately 5% of current studies were carried out in real agricultural settings. © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
